The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a topic of intense current interest. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The approach is based on a set of axioms that guarantee that a category is equivalent to that of continuous linear operators between Hilbert spaces. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The approach is illustrated with a number of examples. The approach is not intended to be a complete solution to the problem of the foundations of quantum theory, but we believe it to be a significant step in that direction.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that have been difficult to place in the tree of life. We have generated the first genomic and transcriptomic assemblies for two species of myxozoans, and compared them to the genome of a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister group to the group that includes the corals. We also find that myxozoans are one of the most reduced animal groups, with a small genome and a reduced gene content. This suggests that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic one was accompanied by a reduction in genome size and gene content. This may be a common theme in the evolution of parasites. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune system is a common defense strategy that they use to replicate and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that SARS-CoV-2 ORF6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This mechanism may be used by other viruses as well. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. We show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the future, even if the mean yield increases. This is due to the fact that the temperature variability of the growing season will increase, and the increase in temperature variability will be larger than the increase in mean temperature. This will have important implications for the stability of global grain trade and the food security of the world’s poor.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown, despite its importance for understanding the coexistence of species and the structure of ecosystems. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in body size, digestive physiology, and location, the diets of these species differed substantially. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, but dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that large mammal diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This may have important implications for the management of large mammal populations and the conservation of biodiversity. (Abridged)

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of pollution in the ocean. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris is mostly concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres, but the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of plastic debris in the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The history of the Sun and the Solar System is recorded in the composition of the elements in the solar system. The history of the Solar System is also recorded in the composition of the elements in the interstellar medium. We determined the history of the Solar System from the composition of the elements in the interstellar medium.

We provide a comprehensive picture of the evolution of the global fishing fleet, its fishing effort, and the engine power of the different sectors. We show that the global fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and that the motorized fleet has expanded substantially, particularly the powered-artisanal fleet. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased by a fifth since 1950, and the global effective CPUE has decreased by a third. We show that the global fleet will continue to expand, but at a slower rate, and that the effective CPUE will continue to decrease. We conclude that the global fleet is unsustainable and that the effective CPUE is decreasing at a rate that is not sustainable. We also show that the powered-artisanal fleet is the most important contributor to the expansion of the global fleet. We suggest that the powered-artisanal fleet should be the focus of sustainable management.

The ability to increase the energy available to the mother is a key component of the evolution of domestication and allonursing. We show that the increase in energy availability is a strong driver of reproductive output and that the increase in reproductive output is a strong driver of the evolution of domestication and allonursing. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is a strong driver of the evolution of domestication and allonursing.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, its monomeric and oligomeric forms, and with neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, controlling vascular contractility, hemostasis, and inflammation, and regulating the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is a highly specialized, yet adaptable and multifunctional cell type. The communication system between cells is poorly understood. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The findings reveal that the endothelial network design is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. This is important for understanding the function of the endothelium and for developing new therapies for cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health crisis, and the data needs of the public health community have been enormous. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides a common interface to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We provide examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be a valuable resource for the public health community.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide variety of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selective permeation of K+ ions. The activation gate is the part of the channel that opens and closes the channel. We have identified a key residue in the activation gate that is functionally and structurally coupled to the selectivity filter. We have also demonstrated that the collapse of the selectivity filter can lead to the structural transition of the channel from the closed to the open state. This study provides a structural explanation for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a structural basis for the control of the selectivity filter in the open and closed states. This knowledge will be useful for the development of drugs that target potassium channels. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is being investigated in a variety of animal models, including humans. The gut microbiome is also a dynamic system that is influenced by the host and the host environment. The study of the gut microbiome is a rapidly evolving field, and the potential of anaerobic fungi to contribute to the health of the host is just beginning to be explored.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies is poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in a social encounter, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that this link is mediated by the brain’s energy metabolism and that pharmacological modulation of mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens can prevent the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. Our findings highlight the importance of mitochondrial function in the brain for social behavior and point to the nucleus accumbens as a potential target for the treatment of anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical devices with desired responses is a critical issue in the field of mechanical engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design multifunctional structures with multiple material phases, which are digitally synthesized through a free-form inverse design approach. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically realized. The proposed strategy can be extended to design multifunctional architectures with complex responses. The designed structures can be applied in various fields, such as robotics, energy harvesting, and biomedical engineering. This work can inspire the design of multifunctional structures with complex responses.

The hemoglobin system is a critical component of the human body, and the expression of the hemoglobin genes is regulated by a variety of factors. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of the expression of the hemoglobin genes. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is down-regulated during development. In addition, we show that IGF2BP1 can mediate the loss of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is required for the expression of the fetal hemoglobin genes. These results suggest that IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of the expression of the hemoglobin genes and may be a target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, in cancer cells. We found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which is highly frequent in cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance. This resistance is mediated, at least in part, by the transcription factor sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1) and the fatty acid desaturase stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), which are downstream targets of SREBP1. We also found that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction, and that this sensitivity can be restored by ectopic expression of SREBP1 or SCD1. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway may be a promising strategy for overcoming ferroptosis resistance in cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are effective, but they have side effects. We show that the most common drugs in this class activate a pathway that promotes vascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the United States. We show that the policy was not effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but did halt the decline of early-seral–associated bird populations. The policy was effective in halting the loss of older forests, but the rate of loss of older forests has not slowed. The NWFP is a unique case study for evaluating the effectiveness of a policy that is still in place.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a long and expensive process, which is often unsuccessful. Therefore, it is essential to develop computational approaches to identify promising candidates early in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best candidate was synthesized and tested in vitro and in vivo. The results show that the best compounds designed by us are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin. This approach can be used to develop new antibiotics in the future. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, and the number of parameters required to achieve accurate results is often not known. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and is easier to train and apply. The network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The network architecture is simple to implement, train, and apply, and automatically adapts to different problems. We show that the proposed network architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We believe that the proposed network architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. We interpret this as a change in the source of climate variability, from orbital forcing to a more chaotic, stochastic regime. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of such devices can have a negative impact on sleep. Specifically, the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime can delay the circadian clock, suppress melatonin, and reduce alertness the following morning. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a short-term cooling that occurred at ∼12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the YDB is consistent with Os from terrestrial sources. In contrast, the YDB site in Pennsylvania is remarkable in yielding 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules containing minerals such as suessite (Fe-Ni silicide) that form at temperatures in excess of 2000 °C. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the spherules and their leachates are often low, but Os in these objects is likely terrestrially derived.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This suggests that the loss of CTLA-4 in adulthood is a more relevant model for the study of autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the history of this group remains poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive view of the evolution of beetles, including the origins of their major feeding habits, and show that the evolution of these habits was driven by the convergent acquisition of genes that enable the digestion of plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

We show that the size of the population in which people learn about artifacts can have a significant impact on the performance of the artifacts that they create. We also show that the size of the population can have a negative impact on the performance of the artifacts, and that this can be a result of the increased variation in the population overwhelming the working memory of the participants.

Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to late-onset Alzheimer’s disease is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the mantle by a sharp boundary. It is one of the most mysterious parts of the Earth. The formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. The nucleation mechanism of the inner core is one of the most important issues. We found that the nucleation of the inner core is more likely to be a two-step process, instead of direct nucleation of the stable, hexagonal, close-packed phase of iron. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is illegal, it is widely available, and its use is increasing. The present study provides evidence that the brain’s reactivity to the drug is reduced, which may contribute to the drug’s addictive properties.
We show that the most powerful artificial neural networks in the world can be used to understand the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in the last few years, but it is still in its infancy. It is now entering scientific computing with full force. However, the stability of neural networks (NNs) has been a major concern. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable NNs, but there does not exist any algorithm that can train (or compute) such a NN. This is a paradox, and we explain it by showing that the existence of stable NNs is not a sufficient condition for the existence of algorithms that can train them. We introduce a new algorithm, fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we prove and numerically verify to be stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. This is a step toward a classification theory of stability and algorithms for deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a case study in the dangers of overreliance on flawed research. The classic experiment used in the analysis of the pandemic’s spread is a case in point. It is discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which are very similar in size, genome content, and gene content. Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources in quantum information science. They are also the two main ingredients of thermodynamics, the latter being the foundation of the physical world. Therefore, the study of entanglement and entropy is of paramount importance for the understanding of the physical world. However, the study of entanglement and entropy is extremely difficult, and so far, only a few exact results are available. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is exact and holds for both interacting and noninteracting systems.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has killed millions of people worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vectors. We describe a live attenuated virus vaccine that is highly protective against COVID-19. This vaccine is temperature sensitive, which allows for easy manufacturing and storage. It is also easy to manufacture in large quantities, which is important for mass vaccination programs.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) was the longest and most devastating of the four pandemics of plague. It led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. We present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study has implications for our understanding of the history of plague and the spread of disease in Europe. It also has implications for the spread of disease in the present day.

The brain is the most complex organ in the human body. It is also the most plastic, allowing us to learn and adapt to our environment. The evolution of the brain is therefore a key question in the history of life. We present a new method to reconstruct the evolution of brain size and neuron numbers in amniotes, which is based on the analysis of the number of neurons in the brain. We show that the evolution of brain size and neuron numbers is very different in reptiles, birds, and mammals. This has important implications for the study of the evolution of brain size and cognition.
We have identified a role for TRAP1 in the regulation of metabolism and cell invasiveness. This is the first report of a role for TRAP1 in the regulation of metabolism.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in the disassembly of actin filaments. It does so by severing filaments, but the mechanism is not well understood. Here, we show that ADF can induce a mechanical torque on filaments, which is enhanced in the presence of a binding partner. This mechanism, which we call “torsional activation,” is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks. We propose that it is a general mechanism that is used by other proteins to enhance their activity.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is widely used in the food supply. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior have not been systematically studied. We show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of fructose on brain and behavior and may help to explain the increased prevalence of obesity in the United States.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian people, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent demographic growth, but the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It is also a reminder that the history of Madagascar is not the history of a single population, but the history of many populations. This is a key message for the future of Madagascar.

We show that the content of people’s Facebook News Feeds can influence their emotions. We find that, when people see more positive content in their News Feed, they post more positive content, and when they see more negative content, they post more negative content. This work suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they do not interact with them in person. This is a significant finding, as it suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they do not interact with them in person. It also suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society.

The presence of RNA modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been known for decades, but the impact of these modifications on protein synthesis has been less well studied. We have developed a method to reconstitute the bacterial translation system in the laboratory and have used this system to study the effects of one of the most common modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), on protein synthesis. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This study provides a foundation for future studies on the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis. (Show more)

We show that the feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces and respond accordingly. This mechanism is important for the pathogenicity of the bacterium, as it promotes the production of virulence factors and biofilm formation. The results also suggest that type IV pili may be used as a mechanochemical sensor, where changes in the mechanical activity of the pili are translated into changes in the activity of a chemosensory system. This mechanism may be important for other bacterial species as well.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is not well understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 can be transmitted between deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study highlights the need for a better understanding of the role of animals in the spread of COVID-19. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the history of the development of hydropower, the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, and the challenges that need to be addressed. We propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a global health crisis. The disease is believed to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, which form plaques and tangles, respectively. However, we show that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ is a significant cause of inflammation, which may be a critical step in the development of AD. This finding has implications for the development of new treatments, since targeting the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a more effective approach than targeting the plaques themselves.

The history of the chicken is one of the most important and most widely studied topics in the field of archaeology. However, the earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens remains elusive. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant in the fourth century B.C.E. and that the earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. We have developed a method that allows us to study the folding of proteins at the molecular level. This method is based on the use of hydrogen exchange to determine the structure of the protein in solution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a large protein that is known to have a native-like intermediate in its folding pathway. We have found that the intermediate is not the only step in the folding pathway and that the pathway is more complex than previously thought. This study is a step toward understanding the mechanism of protein folding. (Show more)

We report the discovery of a previously unknown role for the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, a protein that is known to be involved in the decay of 5′ ends of RNA. We show that, in the presence of disulfide stress, RppH decapsulates Np4-capped RNAs, which are known to accumulate in such conditions. We also show that RppH decapsulates Np4-capped RNAs by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to decapsulate other RNAs. This discovery has implications for our understanding of the role of alarmones in bacteria and for the design of new antibacterial agents. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. Although the immune system is the main player in the resolution of sepsis, it is also the main target of the inflammatory response. We show that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is a key molecule in the immune dysfunction observed in sepsis. We also show that citrulline, the metabolic product of arginine, is a promising molecule to restore the immune system in sepsis.

We provide a census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life, which is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of humans is comparable to that of all plants. We also show that the biomass of humans is comparable to that of all animals, and that humans are the most abundant consumers on the planet.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system, when perturbed, returns to a state of activity at a rate that is proportional to the magnitude of the perturbation. This is a very general phenomenon, which has been observed in a variety of systems, from earthquakes to neural networks. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be tuned by strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This is a significant advance in the understanding of the mechanical stability of diamond, and it can be used to explore the properties of metallized diamond, such as its electronic and optical properties, and its potential applications. This work can also be used to explore the properties of other materials, such as graphene, via machine learning. This is a significant advance in the understanding of the mechanical stability of diamond, and it can be used to explore the properties of metallized diamond, such as its electronic and optical properties, and its potential applications. This work can also be used to explore the properties of other materials, such as graphene, via machine learning.

The discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides is of great interest for the development of new strategies for the control of plant fungal diseases. Here, we report the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides, which are highly diverse in sequence and structure. The structure of one of the peptides was solved by NMR spectroscopy. The antifungal activity of the peptide was demonstrated in vitro and in vivo. The mode of action of the peptide was also elucidated. This work provides a basis for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and the extent of molecular continuity between the sexes is largely unknown. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm is modified after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the proteome of sperm, and that these contributions are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of Drosophila sperm and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. We show that force can switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for the fast binding that is required for the rapid formation of platelet aggregates. This mechanism is important for the rapid formation of platelet aggregates that is required for the rapid formation of platelet aggregates that is required for stopping bleeding.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the study of human-associated viruses, and is a resource for the study of the human microbiome as a whole.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the ACI is complex and difficult to be observed. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe simultaneously aerosol and cloud properties. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the origin and evolution of life. The temperature inferred from the isotopic record is in broad agreement with other lines of evidence, but uncertainties remain. We here present a method for determining the temperature history of the Earth based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that the temperature of the Earth decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. This study highlights the potential of integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data to provide new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Abridged)

Ion channels are the gatekeepers of ion flow. They are activated and deactivated by two gates, one at the intracellular end and the other at the selectivity filter. We found that the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. (Show more)

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in the world today. The parasite, Plasmodium, invades the red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The process of invasion is a complex process, and the role of the host cell in this process has been largely ignored. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the process of invasion and suggests that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces. This finding has implications for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be modified to improve their performance. Here, we show that diamond can be transformed from a semiconductor to a metal by applying strain. This opens up new possibilities for the design of devices and materials with tailored properties.

Influenza is a highly contagious disease that causes millions of cases and hundreds of thousands of deaths each year. The virus is known to spread more efficiently in dry air, but the impact of dry air on host defense and disease outcome is not well understood. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following influenza challenge. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in mice deficient in caspase-1/11, an enzyme involved in tissue repair. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the mechanisms of dry air-induced disease severity and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat influenza. (Show more)

We show that the brain is sensitive to the structure of sentences, and that this sensitivity is not limited to the left hemisphere. We also show that the brain is sensitive to the structure of phrases, and that this sensitivity is not limited to the right hemisphere.

We have identified a mechanism of differential regulation of two functionally redundant genes, which is a common feature of many genes in the body. This mechanism may be used to regulate the activity of other redundant genes in the body.

Obesity is a major health concern, and the mechanisms that govern overeating are not well understood. Here we describe a circuit in the brain that may be involved in the development of obesity. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus, which is known to induce eating, activates a circuit that includes dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and neurons in the brainstem. This circuit is required for the development of eating in response to stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is a key resource for plant growth and productivity, and the ability to control the establishment of the biological nitrogen fixation (BNF) symbiosis is a powerful tool for improving plant growth and productivity. Here, we describe the development of a synthetic plant-controlled BNF system, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system has the potential to be used to improve the efficiency of BNF in agriculture. (Show more)

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. The results suggest that the program may have contributed to sustainable forest management, but the results are not conclusive.

We show that the web of a spider is a hyperacute acoustic antenna that can detect the presence and location of an acoustic wave. The spider can remotely sense the direction and distance of the source of the wave, and it can also localize the wave in the air. The spider can also adjust the size of the acoustic antenna to its needs. This is a unique feature for studying acoustic sensing and for designing acoustic flow detectors.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives and has had a devastating impact on the global economy. The development of vaccines is a critical step in the fight against the pandemic. In this study, we report the design and engineering of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale manufacturing. The engineered protein is highly manufacturable, has high affinity to the ACE2 receptor, and induces strong neutralizing antibodies. The engineered protein can be presented on a virus-like particle to reduce the weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results provide a promising approach for the development of vaccines against SARS-CoV-2. This approach can be extended to other viruses that use the ACE2 receptor for entry into cells. (Show more)

We show that the zebrafish homolog of the ALK oncogene, DrLtk, is a functional receptor for the secreted ALKAL proteins. We further show that the ALKAL proteins are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This study provides a molecular basis for the involvement of ALK in the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the emergence of Yersinia pestis from its progenitor, Yersinia pseudotuberculosis, is one of the most dramatic events in the history of microbiology. We present a large dataset of ancient Y. pestis genomes, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during the formative years of its evolution. Our results suggest that the pathogen was not highly diverse during this period, and that it underwent a series of stepwise changes in its genome. We also discovered the presence of a flea-adapted form of the pathogen in the Bronze Age of Iberia, which suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of the pathogen than previously thought. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague. (Abridged)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump. We found that, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the relationship between masculinity and political extremism.

Agriculture is the leading cause of global greenhouse gas emissions. The conversion of grasslands to crop production has led to massive losses of soil carbon (C) to the atmosphere. We show that the adoption of soil health management practices, such as reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations, and manure addition, can increase soil C storage and the amount of C stored in the more stable mineral-associated organic matter. These practices can be used to mitigate climate change and are particularly effective in grasslands.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We present a systematic approach to identify and prioritize the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We also provide a platform for the public to access and contribute to the ongoing process of identifying and prioritizing the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. The color of nectar is often used as a proxy for the color of the reward, but this is not always the case. We show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a similar red nectar in the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. This work suggests that the red nectar trait is a convergently evolved adaptation, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a new alkaloid for the chemical literature. (Show more)

We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from the late 5th/early 6th century AD, who lived in present-day Bavaria, Germany. We show that the genetic ancestry of the men is mostly of northern and central European origin, but that the women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and may help in the development of strategies to prevent future outbreaks. This article is protected by copyright

We describe the use of a cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to identify the regional pathogen landscape and emerging pathogens in a resource-scarce setting. We show that vector-borne pathogens are the most common clinical category, but that underappreciated zoonotic pathogens, such as Plasmodium knowlesi, leptospirosis, and coinfecting HIV, are also detected. Early detection of chikungunya virus presaged a larger national outbreak of more than 6,000 cases. We demonstrate the feasibility of pathogen-agnostic mNGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce Southeast Asia and the potential for deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and to inform the development of public health response. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and to inform the development of public health response.

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that requires the concerted action of multiple proteins. One of the most important proteins involved in the replication of the lagging strand is pol δ, which is responsible for synthesizing the Okazaki fragments. We have developed a unique kinetic assay to measure the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. The results indicate that the pol δ holoenzyme is not very processive and dissociates from PCNA very quickly. This behavior is important for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the dynamics of the pol δ holoenzyme and its role in the replication of the lagging strand. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. The RNA world hypothesis suggests that life may have originated from the self-replicating, informational function of RNA. In this study, we demonstrate that an RNA polymerase ribozyme can be evolved to synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a significant step toward the realization of the RNA world.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

COVID-19 is a severe disease with high mortality. The treatment is still in the stage of clinical trial. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is a monoclonal antibody targeting interleukin 6, could improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to sequester copper and use it for growth is well established, but the role of natural products in this process has not been explored. We have identified a natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. This work suggests that the ability of fungi to sequester copper and use it for growth is a conserved mechanism for mediating interactions with competing microbes. This work also suggests that the presence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi may be a mechanism for the maintenance of copper homeostasis. This work provides insight into the role of natural products in the maintenance of metal homeostasis and the impact of metal homeostasis on the interactions of fungi with other organisms. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite, a high-temperature, high-pressure polymorph of silica, in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a product of high-temperature, high-pressure metamorphism. The presence of this mineral in a sedimentary rock is even more significant because it is cogenetic with other minerals, indicating that it was deposited at the same time. The presence of this mineral in a sedimentary rock is also significant because it is a product of diagenesis, the process by which sediments are transformed into sedimentary rocks.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of agricultural and forestry crops, and it is also a major concern for the livestock industry. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are also changing. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are also changing. Our findings can help decision-makers in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of the development of Th1-like cells from Th17 precursors is unknown. We show that the development of Th1-like cells is required for the development of colitis and that this process requires the expression of the transcription factor T-bet. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis and suggest that targeting Th17 cells may be a useful therapeutic strategy for certain types of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We have developed a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and test therapeutics. This method will enable the study of disease mechanisms and the rapid testing of therapeutics in ALS.

We describe a mechanism by which a human pathogen, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, alters the gut microbiota of the vector tick, Ixodes scapularis, to enhance its colonization. We show that A. phagocytophilum induces the vector to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the pentapeptide chain of bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work has implications for the control of vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important and enigmatic transitions in the history of life. The discovery of a new early member of the group that gave rise to modern birds, Jinguofortis perplexus, adds to our understanding of the origin of the short tail and the evolution of the avian body plan.
We show that the stratosphere is a major source of climate change, and that this source is not as small as previously thought.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This ability is important for the survival of the animals, as it allows them to adapt to their environment. In this study, we describe a new mechanism of color change, which is based on the binding of biliverdin, a pigment that is part of the hemoglobin, to a protein. This mechanism is present in frogs, and it is the cause of their characteristic green color.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with poor prognosis. We show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene encoding a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is increased in cancer stem cells, and is associated with tumor initiation and metastasis. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins in the production of parchment is a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the origin of animal skins used in the production of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to extract protein from the parchment surface, followed by analysis of the extracted proteins by mass spectrometry. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides.

We have determined the age of the end-Permian mass extinction and the onset of the global carbon cycle reorganization. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Abridged)

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the environment. It is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis and preventing the invasion of pathogens. However, intestinal inflammation is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORα deletion leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. We propose that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of intestinal inflammation. (Show more)

We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in the closed and open states. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein has resulted in a more open conformation. This may facilitate the binding of the virus to the cell surface receptor, ACE2, and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.65 y in 2020, and at age 65 y, 82.18 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry, and they are also of great interest in the study of the origin of the universe, the search for extraterrestrial life, and the search for new materials with exotic properties. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt are pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them are highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the origin of the universe and the search for extraterrestrial life. (Abridged)

We show that the effects of human ignitions and fire suppression on fire activity are likely to be more important in driving future fire regimes than changes in climate. This is important because of the large uncertainties in climate projections and the potential for feedbacks to drive global warming. Our results suggest that the effects of human ignitions and fire suppression on fire activity are likely to be more important in driving future fire regimes than changes in climate. This is important because of the large uncertainties in climate projections and the potential for feedbacks to drive global warming.

We show that the delivery of a single glycan, synthesized by the host, is required for the maturation of the symbiotic community that lives in the crypts of the squid Euprymna scolopes. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn use the resulting metabolites to maintain a stable symbiosis. This glycan is provided only at night, when the squid is active and the crypts are acidic, and is required for the acidification of the crypts. This glycan may be a general cue for the maturation of symbiotic communities in other animals.

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We use a generative model to identify a set of latent topics that are distributed over words in a text. We can also infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. It can be applied to many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. It can also be extended to other types of data, such as images and videos.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the disease originated, were favorable for the survival of the bacterium, and that the climate in Europe was favorable for the spread of the disease. We also show that the climate in Asia was unfavorable for the survival of the bacterium, and that the climate in Europe was unfavorable for the spread of the disease, during the four centuries that followed the first plague introduction. These results suggest that the climate was a key factor in the spread of the disease. (Abridged)

We describe a new disease of sea stars (asteroids) that has been spreading rapidly along the Pacific Coast of North America. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is spread by the infected animals. We also show that the disease has been present in museum specimens for at least 72 y.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach may be applicable to other cancers as well. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian people, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent demographic growth and a sex-biased colonization. In addition, we found that the present genetic structure is influenced by geography, suggesting that the history of Madagascar is not only unique but also complex. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. (Abridged)

Bacteria use small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete.
