The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to accelerate the development of vaccines and therapeutics against COVID-19. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status, and are the most important source of information for the public. However, they are not used in the official crop monitoring systems. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is the most important source of information for the public, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We show that the survey data are statistically robust and maintain similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and have nation-wide validity. We discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed approach can be extended to other crops and countries.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of single neurons. We show that the dynamics of these variables can support memory on multiple timescales, from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. We present the largest global synthesis of soil respiration measurements to date, which reveal no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between warmed and control plots in most biomes. However, in colder biomes, respiration rates with and without experimental warming follow a Gaussian response, increasing with soil temperature up to a threshold of ∼25 °C, above which respiration rates decrease with further increases in temperature. This consistent decrease in temperature sensitivity at higher temperatures demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. (Abridged)

The origin of life is one of the most important questions in biology. The plastid genome, the organelle that is the closest to the ancestral genome, is a key component of the origin of life research. We show that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle, which is the origin of the plastid genome, is linked to the evolution of the molecular structure and the rate of the plastid genome.

The contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the 2015–2017 Cape Town drought has been estimated through observations and climate models. However, model adequacy and insufficient horizontal resolution make it difficult to precisely quantify the changing likelihood of extreme droughts, given the small regional scale. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear SSA rainfall deficits in past and future decades. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. (Abridged)

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the Trinity test, has been a major event in the history of science. It is a story of the power of science to discover new materials, and of the power of history to preserve the memory of that discovery.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, and the light-harvesting pigments are the most important molecules involved. The biosynthesis of these pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of these pigments, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This paper describes the discovery of three classes of the enzyme that catalyzes this reaction, and their evolution is discussed.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of multiple sclerosis and other neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 plays a critical role in the development of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a mouse model of multiple sclerosis. We found that ASK1 is required for the development of EAE, and that ASK1 is required in different glial cell types at different stages of the disease. We propose that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapies for multiple sclerosis.

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to anthropogenic warming.

Autism is a complex disorder with a variety of symptoms, and the etiology is not yet fully understood. We used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the core autistic symptoms and for identifying the causal paths that lead to them. It also provides a potential target for drug development. (Show more)

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. They also highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

We describe a new syndrome, Stormorken syndrome, and identify mutations in STIM1 and ORAI1 that cause this disorder. We also describe a new mechanism of action for STIM1, and suggest a potential therapeutic approach for patients with Stormorken syndrome.

We have developed a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease in which we can visualize the spread of protein aggregates in the brain. We show that the aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, and that this process is important for the spread of the disease. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a platform for studying the mechanisms of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The study of the immune system of bats is of great importance for understanding the immune system of bats and for the development of new strategies for the treatment of human diseases. This study provides a deeper understanding of the immune system of bats and the factors that contribute to the immune suppression of bats. It also provides a new perspective for the study of the immune system of other animals and humans.

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway supporting this growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), a key enzyme in one-carbon metabolism. We show that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. We also show that this inhibitor is effective in inhibiting the growth of a panel of B-cell cancer cell lines, but is ineffective in inhibiting the growth of a panel of other cancer cell lines. Thus, this inhibitor is a promising candidate for the treatment of B-cell cancers.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We show that the proteins that are part of the inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients have a higher average supersaturation than the native interaction partners of these proteins. This suggests that the inclusions are a result of a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a potential mechanism for the formation of inclusions in ALS, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystals are predicted to produce exotic atom–light interactions, including suppressed spontaneous decay, photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal, and emission of light in a direction that is not parallel to the direction of the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The photonic crystal devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This work is a step toward the development of a 2D photonic crystal quantum simulator.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic, and the discovery of Montsechia, a new genus and species, is a major advance in our understanding of the early evolution of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in the field of virology. However, the evolution of viruses is difficult to study, as they are small, noncellular, and difficult to culture. We have used ancient DNA sequences to study the evolution of human parvovirus B19 (B19V). We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This study also shows that ancient DNA sequences can be used to study the evolution of viruses in different environments, such as the Arctic. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This is a clear sign of climate change. However, the rate of rise is not uniform around the world, and it is not clear why some regions are rising faster than others. We show that the rate of rise is accelerating because of the combined effects of thermal expansion of the ocean and the melting of the ice sheets.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain prevalence has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that this increase is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. If this pattern continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity, which is key to understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This study highlights the power of the integrated application of solid-state NMR, X-ray crystallography, and first-principles computational chemistry to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of enzyme mechanisms. This approach is expected to be broadly applicable to the study of enzyme mechanisms. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease with a high mortality rate. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the current standard of care is supportive care. We show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is used to treat Ebola virus disease, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance, given the current global spread of this disease.

We show that the delivery of a single glycan, synthesized by the host, is required for the maturation of the symbiotic community that lives in the crypts of the squid Euprymna scolopes. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn use the resulting metabolites to maintain a stable symbiosis. This glycan is provided only at night, when the squid is active and the crypts are acidic, and is required for the acidification of the crypts. This glycan may be a general cue for the maturation of symbiotic communities in other animals.

This paper describes a series of experiments that show that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed. The findings have implications for the future of education, as well as for the design of interventions to reduce suspension rates.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage and is involved in the etiology of a variety of human diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcription of a lacZ reporter gene. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions can induce distinct transcriptional stalling profiles and that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. The findings are expected to provide important insights into the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis and transcriptional stalling in vivo. This study also provides a potential strategy for the development of novel anticancer drugs. (Show more)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We show that sequential proteolysis of MERS-CoV S proteins is required for virus infection into human lung-derived cells, but not into other cell types. This cell type-specific requirement for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

This paper provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can have a significant impact on meal selection behavior. This has important implications for the food service industry and for the broader policy debate on the role of food in the climate emergency.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. We have developed a method to measure the surfaceome of a single cell, and have applied it to six of the most prominent oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. We also find that the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome in a cell autologous fashion. This is a major advance in our understanding of cancer.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune suppression and evasion. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of the disease and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major risk factor for edema. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of edema in hypoxia are not well understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats, and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1, which triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the development of edema in hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 agonists may be useful in the treatment of edema in hypoxia. (Show more)

The scientific method is based on the idea that we can learn from experience. But what if we have not had a fair chance to learn? What if we have been biased by the data that we have collected? What if we have been influenced by the methods that we have used? This paper addresses these issues and describes a new way of thinking about the scientific method. It is a way of thinking that is based on the idea that we should not be surprised if our conclusions are not correct.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the formation of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs from nonvascular cells is still a challenge. Here, we report the generation of endothelial cells from nonvascular cells by using a single transcription factor, ets variant 2 (ETV2). This study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. Furthermore, the generation of ETVECs may provide a platform for the study of human EC development.

We describe the discovery of two new ligand families for the receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also show that these ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a unique type of dermal chromatophore. Finally, we demonstrate that these ligands are important for the development of iridophores in the eye. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a foundation for understanding the function of Alk and Ltk in vivo. It also provides a foundation for understanding the function of augmentor ligands in vivo. This work is important for understanding the function of Alk and Ltk in vivo. It also provides a foundation for understanding the function of augmentor ligands in vivo.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder that is associated with insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. In this study, we found that STING, a key molecule of innate immune response, plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. STING deficiency in β-cells caused a loss of nuclear factor of activated T cells 1 (NFAT) and Pax6, which are important transcription factors for insulin gene expression. These results suggest that STING is required for the maintenance of insulin secretion and may be a potential therapeutic target for T2D. This study also provides a new perspective for the study of the role of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are able to change their genome sequence and thus their phenotype, which is a major concern for the development of vaccines. The packaging of the genome is a key step in the assembly of the virus particles. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and nonspecifically decreases the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, which might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with the disruption of local hemodynamics. The present study demonstrates that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerosis. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis.

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, which is absent in insects. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropod evolution, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the molecular adaptation of plants and arthropods. (Show more)

Zika virus (ZIKV) has been linked to a variety of severe health problems, including microcephaly and other congenital abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the virus is thought to replicate within cells of the immune system. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We find that the virus replicates rapidly and that the time between infection and the production of infectious virus is likely short. We also find that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is likely in the range of 5,500 to 10,000. Finally, we show that antiviral treatment can be effective in reducing the time to undetectable plasma viral load. However, the timing of treatment is critical, and treatment given too late is mostly ineffective. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on Earth, but they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. One of the most severe threats is the ongoing bleaching event, which is driven by global warming. We show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which is a consequence of the metabolic stress imposed by heat stress. This finding provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may help us to understand the stability of endosymbiotic communities in general.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication between the host and the microbiome. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn activate JNK signaling and trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome. This leads to a dysbiotic microbiome and a further increase in tumor burden. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for the development of therapies targeting JNK signaling in cancer and intestinal diseases. They also suggest that the microbiome may be a potential target for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to it. We show that treatment with chemotherapy can increase the expression of the ROR1 receptor in breast cancer cells, which can enhance the ability of these cells to invade the extracellular matrix, form spheroids, and survive treatment with paclitaxel. We also show that the humanized anti-ROR1 antibody cirmtuzumab can reduce the ability of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft mice, and that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel is more effective than treatment with either alone. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

We show that the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation, which is widely attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, is instead linked to a series of massive volcanic eruptions.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which is the first of its kind. We find that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis reveals that freshwater fisheries are particularly important for the nutrition and livelihoods of the poor and undernourished. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited in aqueous Li-ion batteries. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with LixNb

We describe a form of regeneration in the nervous system that is independent of the canonical signaling pathways that mediate regeneration in other systems. This discovery is important because it provides a platform for the discovery of genes that control the process.

The process of recombination is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in populations and in the genome as a whole. We have developed a method to precisely locate recombination events in a wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. This allowed us to identify the location of recombination events in a natural population, and to compare this to the recombination pattern in a model organism. We find that recombination is more likely to occur in the promoter regions of genes than in the coding regions, and that the recombination pattern is more complex than previously thought.

The brain is a dynamic system, and the study of its resting state is a major challenge in neuroscience. We have developed a method to identify and characterize the resting state of the brain, based on the analysis of metabolic imaging. This method is able to identify the dominant resting state in healthy subjects, and to characterize the resting state in Parkinson’s disease. The results suggest that the resting state is a dynamic organization of the brain, which is altered in disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is involved in many other processes. The existence of 5′ modifications in other RNAs, such as tRNA, has been known for a long time, but the existence of 5′ modifications in mRNA has been debated. We show that 5′ NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. This finding has implications for the role of 5′ NAD-RNA in mRNA metabolism and for the origin of 5′ modifications in mRNA.

We show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in blood cells are associated with glycemia for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT). This is an important finding, as it provides a possible epigenetic explanation for the metabolic memory phenomenon, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the DCCT on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a brain disorder, but the mechanisms involved in the development of the disease are not fully understood. In this study, we show that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the gut barrier and in the development of behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in the flavor of tomato fruit is not well understood. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also describe the discovery of a pathway for the biosynthesis of these compounds, which is distinct from the known pathways for the biosynthesis of other volatile chemicals. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. (Show more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to reflect different aspects of space. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to image the activity of a large number of neurons in the MEC and parasubiculum during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells, which are thought to encode the spatial structure of the environment, are anatomically segregated from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These data suggest that grid cells may have a unique organization that is distinct from that of other cell types. This work provides a framework for understanding the organization of the MEC and its role in navigation. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not the only gene that is involved in the regulation of flowering time. We show that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the Cuscuta australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. We show that the striatonigral fibers that project from the substantia innominata to the striatum form a specialized system that is disrupted in Parkinson’s disease. This system is composed of a unique type of cluster of cell bodies in the ventral tegmental area, which project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Within the cluster, striosomal fibers and dopamine-containing dendrites are tightly intertwined and are connected to other cell types. We suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to the function of the nigrostriatal system in health and disease.

We are social creatures, and we are socialized to believe that we are connected to others by the quality of our social interactions. But how do we know when two people are connected? We show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust predictor of felt connection. This signal is used by others to judge the quality of the connection between two people, and it is used by the people themselves to signal their connection to others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. We report here that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in these cells and plays a role in the regulation of the SAN.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has been controversial. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is associated with an increase in jasmonic acid (JA) levels and defense gene expression. These results suggest that Si may be a promising strategy for the management of insect pests. This study also provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of Si-mediated plant defense. We show that tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor for nitric oxide synthesis and aromatic amino acid hydroxylation, is also involved in ether lipid metabolism. This is of importance for the understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in the metabolism of other lipids. We also show that the activity of a specific enzyme, alkylglycerol monooxygenase, is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids and that it is important for the activation of macrophages.

Language is a uniquely human ability. It is thought to be the result of a long evolutionary process that has led to the development of a specialized brain. Here we propose a computational neurobiology of language that is based on the idea that language is a form of memory. We show that the dynamics of single neurons can be used to represent information in memory. This is done through the development of a mechanism that reduces the firing rate of neurons and can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration within the language domain. We believe that this work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It may also have implications for other domains of memory and cognition.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic substances. Thus, plants are exposed to a variety of toxic substances in the environment, which can cause damage to the plant. Therefore, it is important to develop methods to protect plants from toxic substances. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) to plants, which can silence the expression of a target gene. This work provides a method to protect plants from toxic substances.

We show that the majority of the nutrients that fuel algal blooms in the nearshore areas of large lakes come from small tributaries. These findings have important implications for the management of coastal ecosystems, which are often the most valuable and threatened areas of lakes.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a thermodynamic forcing that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the dynamics of a system of coupled oscillators, and we show that the network can be modeled as a network of coupled oscillators. We also show that the network can be used to model the dynamics of a physical system, and we discuss the implications of our results for the design of chemical systems.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities, which are believed to be caused by disruption of the receptor. We show that NMDAR-Abs can change the dynamics of the brain, and that this can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This is the first study to show that the dynamics of the brain can be changed by antibodies. This could have implications for the treatment of autoimmune encephalitis.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of the Earth system, and the history of carbon perturbation events is a key component of the history of abrupt climate change. Here, we present a study of one of the most extreme events in the history of Earth’s carbon cycle, which occurred during a glacial period.

We show that the world’s largest palm oil certification scheme, the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil, has had a positive impact on reducing deforestation. However, the scheme has not yet had a significant impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection. We argue that the certification scheme needs to be expanded to forested areas, and that certification requirements need to be strengthened to ensure that deforestation is avoided in peatlands and that there is no active fire.

The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for organisms across kingdoms. However, the molecular mechanism of the exocyst complex and its regulation are not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in the evolution of animals, and the sex of an individual is often a key determinant of reproductive success. In many species, the sex of an individual is determined by a single genetic locus. In others, multiple genetic loci interact to determine sex. In this study, we show that the sex of a species can be modularly determined by multiple interacting sex determination loci, and that this can lead to the evolution of a variety of sexual phenotypes.

The retina is a unique organ in that it is a major site of Fe metabolism. We show that Fe levels in the retina are critical for the redox state of the cell and the photoreceptor cell viability. We also show that Fe levels in the retina can be manipulated by the use of a chelator. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of Fe in the retina and may lead to the development of new therapies for retinal disease. (Show more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystem functioning, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of biodiversity. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve morphological and functional optimizations in separate structures. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, are an exception to this rule. We show that siphonophores can evolve from generalists to specialists, and that specialists on one prey type can evolve into specialists on other prey types. Our findings help to understand the evolution of specialization, and how it has shaped the present-day food web.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure. The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in the study of human evolution. This study provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process.

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway supporting this growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), a key enzyme in one-carbon metabolism. We show that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. We also show that this inhibitor is effective in inhibiting the growth of a panel of B-cell cancer cell lines, but is ineffective in inhibiting the growth of a panel of other cancer cell lines. This latter observation suggests that the one-carbon metabolism of B-cell cancer is more sensitive to inhibition than other cancer types.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change, and the resulting loss of biodiversity is well documented. However, the impact of deforestation on people’s diets is less well understood. We show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this can be mitigated by the presence of forests. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Agriculture is the main driver of the global food production, and mechanization has been a key contributor to the expansion of food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the increase in subsoil compaction risk is a consequence of the increase in the total weight of farm vehicles, which is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods.
